admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
The Child Welfare Reform Project aims to
            improve child welfare in Romania through testing and
            promoting community-based child welfare approaches as
            sustainable and cost-effective alternatives to
            institutionalized child care and for re-integrating street
            children in Bucharest more fully into society. There are 3
            components. The Community-Based Child Welfare Services
            component identifies, finances, monitors, and evaluates
            sub-projects over a period of 42 months, with the goal of
            preventing child abandonment and institutionalization, and
            de-institutionalizing and improving the quality of
            residential care by alternative community-based services. It
            provides family counseling and support, educates young
            parents, provides temporary shelter for young single mothers
            and their babies, provides day care for children at risk as
            well as therapeutic care for children with special needs,
            sets up small group homes that are community-integrated
            alternative residential care facilities providing
            short/medium term care, and aids foster care training
            services. The second component expands an existing center
            for coordination and information on street children,
            provides services for them and reduces their number,
            focusing on night and day shelters, counseling and legal
            advice, learning and educational facilities, and medical
            assistance. The third component, supports the Department for
            Child Protection (DCP) in overseeing project implementation,
            trains staff, and spreads public awareness.
